repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - National Water Rehabilitation,
            First Multi-State Water Supply, and Small Towns Water Supply
            and Sanitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Rehabilitation, the
            First Multi-State, and the Small Towns Water Supply projects
            were selected for this cluster assessment in order to
            evaluate the reasons for the failure of the Bank's
            assistance to the Nigerian water supply sector in the
            1979-2004 period.  These projects represent a clear
            evolution in the scope of World Bank lending: the first
            project was nationwide and concentrated on procurement and
            installation of equipment in selected water systems in each
            of the 36 Nigerian states and the National Federal
            Territory; the second project was restricted to two states
            (Kaduna and Katsina); and the third project directly
            assisted 16 small towns. This assessment rated the outcome
            of the National Water Rehabilitation Project as highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, negligible
            institutional development Impact, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower.  For the First
            Multi-State Water Supply Project, the assessment concurred
            with the completion report, except that the PPAR rated the
            outcome as moderately satisfactory. The PPAR rated the
            outcome of the Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project as satisfactory with likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            There are three principal lessons: First, the targets under
            the MDGs for water supply and sanitation, focusing only on
            service coverage and access, need to be expanded to include
            the reliability and quality of water supplies.  Second,
            effective coordination between central, state and local
            governments requires demand-driven approaches where the
            consumers have the initiative. Third, maintenance merits
            priority over new works.

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. The following lessons
            reflect in part, an increased awareness on the need for
            major institutional reforms. The commercialization of public
            institutions was hindered namely by the Government's
            unwillingness to give autonomy, without which sustainable,
            commercial institutional arrangements do not succeed. This
            was further exacerbated by the disparity of water demand
            estimates as related to the prices charged: it shows water
            being sold very cheaply, highly subsidized, with a large
            over-capacity. Regrettably, the Bank failed to pursue this
            issue further. Dependence on external factors should be
            carefully assessed, for while the project did provide
            standby generators, electricity Boards were unable to pay
            for the additional, operational fuel costs, which indicates
            particular attention should be given to supporting sectors
            of the economy when same are not thriving. Moreover,
            institutional development by and large, must be viewed as a
            continuum, based on a programmed approach, where
            institutional changes demand more radical interventions from
            both the utility in question, and the state government.
            Finally, resettlement issues require a pragmatic assessment
            by the Bank, rather than the purist approach of
            environmental assessment, and, regardless of supervision
            budgets constraints, technical staff can help review, and
            resolve lagging implementation activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Multistate Water Supply
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Multistate Water Supply
            Project for Nigeria aims to support economic growth by
            enhancing health and productivity of urban areas, helping to
            alleviate poverty by improving health standards of the
            lowest income urban households and the living conditions of
            women. Negative measures include: water pollution, dust, air
            pollution, noise pollution, waste management, soil erosion,
            and pest management. Mitigation measures include: a) minimum
            tillage technique should be adopted in the catchment area as
            against deep ploughing. The use of animal drawn ploughs
            noticed during the time of visit is a step in the right
            direction; b) use of insect hormones, hormone analogue or
            other chemicals that can mimic the action of insect hormones
            to alter hormone-regulated processes like moulting,
            metamorphosis, reproduction etc; c) biological control of
            pests is the use of pest parasites and predators to wipe out
            unwanted species or populations of pests; d) where
            water-borne sanitation becomes inevitable because of rapid
            urbanization as is expected here, the framework for the
            treatment of sewage should be laid down; and e) water
            pollution control legislation should be reviewed and
            institutional arrangements for enforcement should be established.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to support economic
            growth by enhancing health and productivity of urban areas,
            helping to alleviate poverty by improving health standards
            of the lowest income urban households and the living
            conditions of women.  Primary objectives of the project are
            to improve both the quantity and the reliability of the
            water supply to meet basic needs and as an essential step in
            promoting economic development.  The project includes: 1)
            physical rehabilitation of the existing systems; 2)
            selective increase of supply facilities; 3) improved
            operation and maintenance practices; 4) improved investment
            planning; 5) setting and achieving realistic financial
            objectives; and 6) manpower development.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to support economic
            growth by enhancing health and productivity of urban areas,
            helping to alleviate poverty by improving health standards
            of the lowest income urban households and the living
            conditions of women.  Primary objectives of the project are
            to improve both the quantity and the reliability of the
            water supply to meet basic needs and as an essential step in
            promoting economic development.  The project includes: 1)
            physical rehabilitation of the existing systems; 2)
            selective increase of supply facilities; 3) improved
            operation and maintenance practices; 4) improved investment
            planning; 5) setting and achieving realistic financial
            objectives; and 6) manpower development.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - First Multistate Water Supply
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Multistate Water Supply
            Project for Nigeria aims to support economic growth by
            enhancing health and productivity of urban areas, helping to
            alleviate poverty by improving health standards of the
            lowest income urban households and the living conditions of
            women. Negative measures include: water pollution, dust, air
            pollution, noise pollution, waste management, soil erosion,
            and pest management. Mitigation measures include: a) minimum
            tillage technique should be adopted in the catchment area as
            against deep ploughing. The use of animal drawn ploughs
            noticed during the time of visit is a step in the right
            direction; b) use of insect hormones, hormone analogue or
            other chemicals that can mimic the action of insect hormones
            to alter hormone-regulated processes like moulting,
            metamorphosis, reproduction etc; c) biological control of
            pests is the use of pest parasites and predators to wipe out
            unwanted species or populations of pests; d) where
            water-borne sanitation becomes inevitable because of rapid
            urbanization as is expected here, the framework for the
            treatment of sewage should be laid down; and e) water
            pollution control legislation should be reviewed and
            institutional arrangements for enforcement should be established.
